Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Remote Imaging of Community Ecology via Animal-borne Wireless Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will construct a wireless network of animal-borne embedded devices that will be deployed and tested in a biologically-relevant application. The networked devices will provide not only geo-location data, but also execute cooperative strategies that save battery-life by selectively recording bandwidth-intensive audio and high-definition video footage of occurrences of animal group behavior of interest, such as predation.
This project comprises three concurrent and interdependent research themes. The first is the investigation of methods to design and analyze the performance of distributed algorithms that implement autonomous decisions at the mobile agents, subject to communication and computational constraints. The second will pursue data-driven fundamental research on the modeling of animal group motion and will promote a formal understanding of the mechanisms of social interaction. The third is centered on the investigation of methods for hardware integration to build distributed networks of embedded devices that are capable of executing the newly developed algorithms, subject to power and weight constraints.
The results and experience gained in this project will guide the development of effective autonomous systems for the monitoring and protection of endangered species. This project will create undergraduate and graduate research opportunities at all participating institutions, expanding on an existing collaboration between the University of Maryland, Princeton University, and the National Geographic Society. There is the potential for using wide-reaching media resources to disseminate the results of this project to a broad audience. This may contribute to attracting more students to engineering and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Resulting from close collaboration among the University of Maryland (UMCP), the National Geographic Society (NGS) and Princeton University, this project developed new technologies, algorithms, and theory to design, build, test and deploy an ad-hoc mobile wireless network of monitoring devices. The devices can record GPS trajectories, video and other dynamical variables that can be used to reconstruct the motion and document the environment surrounding each device. 
The following are the main achievements of the University of Maryland's team:
We proposed a new class of omniscience algorithms that allow each device to use information shared through the network to keep track of the essential variables sensed by every other device.  These algorithms enable the implementation of coordination strategies according to which the devices make decisions as a team. In particular, they can cooperatively and efficiently decide when each device should turn on or off the GPS module, camera and adjust wireless transmission power to meet the requirements of the given mission while extending the deployment life by saving onboard battery and memory space. The theoretical analysis and studies of the numerical properties of the algorithms were published in reputable venues, mostly associated with The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE).
In collaboration with NGS, we developed three generations of ever more compact and capable devices. This was accomplished by graduate and undergraduate students who worked under the supervision of a postdoctoral researcher, NGS technical staff, and the PI to custom design new hardware and firmware. Resources at the CPS and Cooperative Autonomy Lab (UMCP) played a significant role in the development and subsequent testing of the devices. Our last step was to create an improved and flexible interface to facilitate setup for cooperative missions. A comprehensive performance study of the underlying ad-hoc wireless network was also carried out to calibrate the power management firmware.
We tested the robustness and performance of our system in real-world applications. In particular, we partnered with The Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute (SCBI) and the Gorongoza National Park, Mozambique. These collaborators used our devices to monitor socio-biological events of interest by mounting the devices on animals during routine health checkups. Each sensor self-releases after the onboard battery is discharged and is recovered via a beacon location system for data download. These deployments lasted, on average, two weeks and served to validate our algorithms and hardware. The data collected by the devices was used for scientific studies carried out by biologists affiliated with our partners and Princeton University. In particular, the data collected from the deployments at Gorongoza will be crucial to document foraging behavior and the dynamics among species as they re-establish normal population levels after being decimated by decades of civil war that ended recently. These studies are likely to be significant to guide nature preservation efforts.
Graduate students, whose dissertations focused on work for this project, gained a unique set of skills which helped them succeed professionally after graduation. Notably, Dr. Shinkyu Park is now a postdoctoral researcher at MIT (CSAIL/Senseable City Lab) working on related projects and Mr. Eli Lorenzi ranked second in the 2018 Dean's Master's Research Award Competition at the College of Engineering of UMCP. Several undergraduate students worked on the firmware and hardware, including Mr. Joshua Drubin, who won the Fall 2013 MHacks competition.
